item.title: [GOOG] How Google’s TPU Assembly Shift Could Reshape Celestica’s Hyperscaler Exposure (TSX:CLS) Investors
item.description: In recent days, reports that Google is shifting some tensor processing unit (TPU) server assembly work from Celestica to additional suppliers have raised questions about the company’s role in future AI infrastructure programs. Amid this customer-sourcing uncertainty, Celestica’s strong positioning in AI data center hardware and networking keeps attention firmly on how much hyperscaler demand it can retain and win. We’ll now examine how Google’s reported TPU server assembly shift shapes...

item.title: [NVDA] Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang in Shanghai amid China regulatory headwinds
item.description: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang is in Shanghai, a person briefed on the matter said ​on Saturday, as the U.S. chip giant faces fierce ‌competition from local rivals and scrutiny from Chinese authorities. The timing of Huang's trip, ‌to kick off annual celebrations with Nvidia's China employees, is routine. He is expected to attend an Nvidia party in Shanghai on Saturday before travelling to Beijing, Shenzhen and then Taiwan, another person with ⁠knowledge of the plans ‌said.

item.title: [GOOG] Legal AI giant Harvey acquires Hexus as competition heats up in legal tech
item.description: Hexus founder and CEO Sakshi Pratap, who previously held engineering roles at Walmart, Oracle, and Google, tells TechCrunch that her San Francisco-based team has already joined Harvey, while the startup's India-based engineers will come onboard once Harvey establishes a Bangalore office.

item.description: SLB N.V. (NYSE:SLB) will release earnings for the fourth quarter before the opening bell on Friday, Jan. 23. Analysts expect the company to report fourth-quarter earnings of 74 cents per share. That's down from 92 cents per share in the year-ago period. The consensus estimate for SLB's quarterly revenue is $9.55 billion (it reported $9.28 billion last year), according to Benzinga Pro. item.title: [GOOG] GE Aerospace Backlog Nears $190 Billion As Airlines Spend Big On Engine Upkeep
item.description: GE Aerospace (NYSE:GE) on Thursday reported strong fourth-quarter 2025 results, reflecting continued momentum across its businesses. It posted total revenue (GAAP) of $12.717 billion, up 18% year over year. Sales of $12.717 billion beat the $11.177 billion estimate, and adjusted EPS of $1.57 beat the $1.43 estimate. Continuing EPS (GAAP) was $2.31, up 32%, and adjusted EPS was $1.57, up 19%. Cash from operating activities was $2.096 billion, up 59%, and free cash flow was $1.760 billion, up 15%.

item.title: [IBM] Is It Time To Reassess IBM (IBM) After Its Recent Share Price Pullback?
item.description: If you are wondering whether International Business Machines (IBM) is still reasonably priced after its long run in tech, this article walks through what the current share price may be implying about value. IBM closed at US$292.44, with a 4.3% decline over the last 7 days and a 4.0% decline over the last 30 days, while its returns stand at 0.3% year to date, 33.5% over 1 year, 142.8% over 3 years and 216.2% over 5 years. These moves have come alongside continued attention on IBM's position...

item.title: [BRH.F] A Winter Storm Is on Track to Hit Insurers. Why the Damage Could Be Huge.
item.description: A major winter storm advancing across the southern and eastern United States this weekend won’t just test municipal snow crews and utility companies’ gridlines. With freezing temperatures, snow, sleet, and ice expected to sweep through millions of households, policyholders will likely file loss reports in the weeks and months ahead, ranging from auto accidents and property damage to burst pipes and roof collapses. Although winter storms are often viewed as less severe weather events than hurricanes or earthquakes, they can lead to meaningful losses for residential and commercial property owners and impact automobiles and infrastructure across a broad swath of the country.

item.title: [AZN.L] Is Daiichi Sankyo (TSE:4568) Turning ENHERTU’s China Approval Into a Durable Oncology Moat?
item.description: Earlier this week, Daiichi Sankyo and AstraZeneca received approval in China for ENHERTU as the first HER2-directed antibody-drug conjugate for second-line treatment of HER2 positive metastatic gastric cancer, based on the DESTINY-Gastric04 phase 3 trial showing a survival benefit over ramucirumab plus paclitaxel. This decision opens access to ENHERTU in a country that accounts for more than one third of global gastric cancer cases, highlighting the importance of Daiichi Sankyo’s oncology...

item.description: Two novel energy companies just filed papers to go public, giving investors a chance to buy into trends that could reshape electricity generation in the coming decade—if they work. Fervo, a geothermal energy company that generates electricity from underground heat, filed confidentially with the SEC to go public, according to Axios. Fervo is one of the most talked-about clean energy companies in private markets, and just raised $462 million in a Series E fund-raising in December.

item.title: [GOOG] Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang Could Owe $8B Under California's 5% Billionaire Tax — But Says 'I Haven't Thought About It Even Once'
item.description: A proposed wealth tax in California has renewed questions about whether billionaires might reconsider where they live and companies choose to build. In a recent Bloomberg interview, Nvidia (NASDAQ:NVDA) CEO Jensen Huang said he has not given the proposal any thought, even though the tax could cost him nearly $8 billion if it becomes law. "I haven't thought about it even once," Huang said. "We work in Silicon Valley because that's where the talent pool is." Don't Miss: Missed Nvidia and Tesla? RA

item.title: [NVDA] The US Has Lost $2.4 Billion on Its Intel Stake Today
item.description: One of Intel’s largest shareholders is the U.S. government, stemming from an August deal that converted some of Intel’s CHIPS Act subsidies into newly issued shares overseen by the Commerce Department. With the stock down 15.2% in midday Friday trading, the government has taken a $2.4 billion loss on the day—but has still notched a 121% return overall since August. Over two tranches, the Commerce Department bought 278 million shares of Intel through the end of last year, at a weighted average price of $20.73.

item.title: [CSCO] 'Jobs, jobs, jobs' the AI mantra as fears take back seat in Davos
item.description: Biting cold, political tensions and doubts about artificial intelligence did nothing to curb the enthusiasm of business leaders in Davos over technology's ability to create jobs. Top executives at the World Economic Forum's annual meeting said that while jobs would disappear, new ones would spring up, with ​two telling Reuters that AI would be used as an excuse by companies which were planning layoffs anyway. Flag bearers of AI's trillion-dollar expansion, including chip titan Jensen Huang, ‌said the technology heralded higher pay and more jobs for plumbers, electricians and steelworkers.

item.title: [NVDA] Intel shares tumble as supply chain snarls hamper turnaround
item.description:
STORY: Intel shares plunged 12% on Friday (January 23).

Investors sold off after the company struggled to meet strong AI demand for data center chips.

It blamed that on supply constraints.

The firm had also forecast quarterly revenue and profit below market estimates

Market watchers were disappointed as many had bet on Intel's turnaround.

The firm is a latecomer to the AI boom and has finally enjoyed a demand surge.

Consumers want its traditional server chips which are used alongside AI processors in data centers.

Investor interest also grew due to investments in the firm from the U.S. government, Softbank and Nvidia.

Intel's stock outpaced most semiconductor firms last year with an 84% gain.

It extended its rally into this year - and was up close to half this month so far.

But the company couldn't keep up with the demand surge even as it runs factories at capacity.

It also warned a spike in memory chip prices could hurt sales in the PC market.

Its new "Panther Lake" PC chips were expected to spark a comeback after years of market share losses to AMD.

The memory chip surge is driven by growing AI demand.

But Intel said it expects available memory supply to improve in the second quarter.

That after hitting its lowest levels in the first quarter.

item.title: [TSM] Taiwan looks forward to more chip investment in Arizona, president says
item.description: Taiwan looks forward to even more semiconductor investment in Arizona to bolster ties with the United States, ​President Lai Ching-te told a visiting senator from the state ‌on Friday. U.S. President Donald Trump has pushed the major producer of semiconductors, which runs a ‌large trade surplus with the United States, to invest more in the U.S., specifically in chips that power AI. TSMC, the world's largest contract chipmaker and producer of the advanced chips powering the artificial intelligence revolution, is investing $165 ⁠billion in Arizona's capital, ‌Phoenix, to build factories.
